title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context-Logarithmic Function, Part B

content.description:
On the initial day of sales (<math alttext="t equals 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>) for a new video game, there were <math alttext="40" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn></math> thousand units of the game sold that day. Ninety-one days later (<math alttext="t equals 91" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>91</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="76" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>76</mn></math> thousand units of the game sold that day. 

The number of units of the video game sold on a given day can be modeled by the function <math alttext="G" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi></math> given by <math alttext="G open parentheses t close parentheses equals a plus b ln open parentheses t plus 1 close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>ln</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, where <math alttext="G open parentheses t close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the number of units sold, in thousands, on day <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> since the initial day of sales.
content.question:
Part B

(i) ​Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of units of the video game sold, in thousands per day, from <math alttext="t equals 0"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math> to <math alttext="t equals 91"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>91</mn> </math> days. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the number of units of the video game sold, in thousands, on day <math alttext="t equals 50"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>50</mn> </math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(iii) Let <math alttext="A subscript t"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> </math> represent the estimate of the number of units of the video game sold, in thousands, using the average rate of change found in (i). For <math alttext="A subscript 50"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mn>50</mn> </msub> </math>, found in (ii), it can be shown that <math alttext="A subscript 50 less than G open parentheses 50 close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mn>50</mn> </msub> <mo><</mo> <mi>G</mi> <mfenced> <mn>50</mn> </mfenced> </math>. Explain why, in general, <math alttext="A subscript t less than G open parentheses t close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> <mo><</mo> <mi>G</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math> for all <math alttext="t"> <mi>t</mi> </math>, where <math alttext="0 less than t less than 91"> <mn>0</mn> <mo><</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo><</mo> <mn>91</mn> </math>.
